ACCT102.title: Principles of Accounting
ACCT102.subject: Accounting
ACCT102.overview: A foundation for further studies in accounts preparation.  Examines underlying concepts, principles and techniques of financial accounting and reporting.

AGRI101.title: Agricultural Innovation
AGRI101.subject: Agriculture
AGRI101.overview: Current issues and solutions in agriculture, including social, commercial, and environmental aspects, and the role of science and technology for driving innovation.

ANAT101.title: Anatomy for Sport and Exercise
ANAT101.subject: Anatomy
ANAT101.overview: Introduction to functional anatomy of the human body, with a focus on biomechanics of normal human movement. Examples in sport and exercise are used to integrate structure and function.

ANAT131.title: Origins of Anatomical Language
ANAT131.subject: Anatomy
ANAT131.overview: An introduction to the study of anatomy throughout history and how anatomical terminology used to this day has roots in classical languages such as Greek and Latin.

ANTH103.title: Introduction to Anthropology
ANTH103.subject: Anthropology
ANTH103.overview: An introduction to the fundamental concepts and history of general anthropology, including archaeology and social anthropology.

ANTH106.title: Human Origins and Civilisations
ANTH106.subject: Anthropology
ANTH106.overview: A review of archaeological evidence for the origins and cultural development of the human species from its earliest appearance up to and including the rise of early civilisations.

ASIA101.title: Introducing Asia
ASIA101.subject: Asian Studies
ASIA101.overview: A multi-disciplinary introduction to the culture and society of Asian countries and regions, with an emphasis on East Asia.

BIBS121.title: Interpreting the New Testament
BIBS121.subject: Biblical Studies
BIBS121.overview: The interpretation of the New Testament in its historical context, including an introduction to critical methods and to the study of the Gospels and the Epistles, with an in-depth discussion of selected texts.

BIBS131.title: Introductory New Testament Greek Language 1
BIBS131.subject: Biblical Studies
BIBS131.overview: A reading-based beginners’ paper covering the basic elements of New Testament Greek grammar and vocabulary, designed to develop reading skills in New Testament Greek.

BIOC192.title: Foundations of Biochemistry
BIOC192.subject: Biochemistry
BIOC192.overview: An introduction to the structure and function of proteins as essential elements of life processes; principles of enzymology; introductory bioenergetics; conservation of the energy of food for body processes; digestion and catabolism of fats, proteins and carbohydrates; terminal pathways of oxidation, anaerobic and aerobic metabolism, mitochondrial metabolism; energy storage and utilisation; the molecular basis of disease; illustrative topics in metabolism.

BIOL112.title: Animal Biology
BIOL112.subject: Biology
BIOL112.overview: An introductory survey of the evolution and diversity of animal life.  Essential biological principles are illustrated using examples from New Zealand fauna, issues of environmental, social or economic importance, and cutting-edge research developments at the University of Otago.

BIOL123.title: Plants: How They Shape the World
BIOL123.subject: Biology
BIOL123.overview: An introduction to botany, how the study of plants aids our understanding of Earth’s history and human society, and how plants will respond to future environmental change.

BSNS111.title: Business and Society
BSNS111.subject: Business Studies
BSNS111.overview: Introduction to the business environment of New Zealand, including important defining characteristics, social and environmental implications of business decisions, and an appreciation of bi- and multi-cultural frameworks as they affect business.

BSNS113.title: Economic Principles and Policy
BSNS113.subject: Business Studies
BSNS113.overview: Introduction to concepts central to understanding market economies, including allocation of scarce resources, consumer and business reactions to changing market conditions, and the application of economic principles to personal and business decision-making.

BSNS114.title: Financial Decision Making
BSNS114.subject: Business Studies
BSNS114.overview: Introduction to some basic characteristics of financial markets. The time value of money, calculations of fair value for bonds and stocks, criteria for financing a business, risk-return trade-offs, regulatory frameworks and ethical considerations are included.

BSNS115.title: Accounting and Information Systems
BSNS115.subject: Business Studies
BSNS115.overview: Introduction to financial and management accounting concepts, including reading and interpreting accounting statements and making internal business decisions. Using information systems and communication technology to manage data, with associated ethical issues.

CELS191.title: Cell and Molecular Biology
CELS191.subject: Cell and Molecular Biology
CELS191.overview: An introduction to the biology of cells; fundamentals of molecular biology; organismal and molecular genetics; human genetic variation; diversity and biology of microorganisms; microbial virulence and disease processes.

CELS199.title: Cell and Molecular Biology
CELS199.subject: Cell and Molecular Biology
CELS199.overview: An introduction to the biology of cells; fundamentals of molecular biology; organismal and molecular genetics; human genetic variation; diversity and biology of microorganisms; microbial virulence and disease processes.

CHEM111.title: Chemistry: Molecular Architecture
CHEM111.subject: Chemistry
CHEM111.overview: An introduction to modern structural chemical science covering: states of matter: gas, liquid, solid, solutions; atomic structure; chemical bonding: stereochemistry, isomerism, conformational analysis; methods of structural determination: spectroscopy (electronic absorption, infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance), mass spectrometry; colloids.

CHEM150.title: Concepts in Chemistry
CHEM150.subject: Chemistry
CHEM150.overview: Introduction to the core ideas and methods of chemistry, recommended for students with limited chemistry backgrounds. Topics include stoichiometry, equilibria, thermochemistry, redox, acid-base chemistry and main group and organic chemistry.

CHEM191.title: The Chemical Basis of Biology and Human Health
CHEM191.subject: Chemistry
CHEM191.overview: An introduction to the concepts of chemistry underlying important processes in biology and human health, including chemical bonding, energetics, kinetics, equilibria and solubility, properties of water and solutions, acids, bases, complexation and electron transfer, mechanisms of organic reactions and properties of amino acids and carbohydrates.

CHIN131.title: Introductory Chinese 1
CHIN131.subject: Chinese
CHIN131.overview: An introductory course in reading, writing, speaking and listening to Chinese for students with no previous knowledge of the language.  The paper takes an integrated approach to the skills of language acquisition and includes basic material on the cultural heritage of the Chinese people.

CHIN132.title: Introductory Chinese 2
CHIN132.subject: Chinese
CHIN132.overview: A continuation of CHIN131, further developing students’ Chinese language skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening at an elementary level.  The paper takes an integrated approach to the skills of language acquisition and includes basic material on the cultural heritage of the Chinese people.

CHTH102.title: The History of Christianity
CHTH102.subject: Christian Thought and History
CHTH102.overview: A survey of the history of Christianity from 100 AD to the present day: from early formation to recent contexts in Nazi Germany, Soviet Russia and North America.

CHTH111.title: Doing Theology
CHTH111.subject: Christian Thought and History
CHTH111.overview: What is theology? How do we do it, and why? Exploring Christian thinking on Jesus Christ, God, the Trinity, salvation, creation, and the last things.

CHTH131.title: God and Ethics in the Modern World
CHTH131.subject: Christian Thought and History
CHTH131.overview: An introduction to Christian ethics in the modern world with particular attention to the major cultural shifts that have shaped contemporary thinking about God, ethics, religion and law.

CLAS105.title: Greek Mythology
CLAS105.subject: Classical Studies
CLAS105.overview: A study of the myths of ancient Greece with particular reference to the origins and nature of gods and heroes.

CLAS109.title: Roman Social History: Slaves, Gladiators, Prostitutes
CLAS109.subject: Classical Studies
CLAS109.overview: A study of ancient Roman social life, with particular emphasis on the marginalised (or so-called ’invisible’) lower classes, including slaves, gladiators, prostitutes and bandits.

COMO101.title: Modelling and Computation
COMO101.subject: Computational Modelling
COMO101.overview: An introduction to mathematical and computational modelling with applications in science, engineering, biomedicine and industry. Topics include the translation of observations into mathematical models, and the use of simulation and numerical methods to evaluate and apply the models.

COMP101.title: Foundations of Information Systems
COMP101.subject: Computer and Information Science
COMP101.overview: Introduction to information systems for the management and exploitation of data and information, and to relational databases.

COMP120.title: Practical Data Science
COMP120.subject: Computer and Information Science
COMP120.overview: An introduction to the techniques used to prepare, integrate, manage and visualise complex data using modern software environments. Essential to students needing to manage data in science, business, or humanities.

COMP161.title: Computer Programming
COMP161.subject: Computer and Information Science
COMP161.overview: An introduction to computer programming suitable for beginners with little or no prior experience. Introduces the Java programming language, basic object oriented concepts, and simple graphical applications.

COMP162.title: Foundations of Computer Science
COMP162.subject: Computer and Information Science
COMP162.overview: An introduction to computer programming suitable for beginners with some prior experience. Builds on and extends basic Java and object oriented programming. Introduces broader programming concepts and other languages.

DANC101.title: Dance and Popular Culture
DANC101.subject: Dance
DANC101.overview: An examination of the role of dance in popular culture in local and global contexts through integrated theory and choreographic exploration.

EAOS111.title: Earth and Ocean Science
EAOS111.subject: Earth and Ocean Science
EAOS111.overview: Your introduction to planet Earth, inside and out. The origin of our universe, oceans, mountains, climate change, and mass extinctions: it’s all connected. Three field trips including a research cruise.

ECOL111.title: Ecology and Conservation of Diversity
ECOL111.subject: Ecology
ECOL111.overview: Species and population ecology: patterns of biodiversity; management of threatened species; evolution and environmental influences; how individuals interact with each other in populations, and with their physical environment.

ECON112.title: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECON112.subject: Economics
ECON112.overview: Introduction to analysing the economy as a whole. Topics include the determination of national income, unemployment, inflation, interest rates and the exchange rate, as well as monetary and fiscal policy.

EDCR101.title: Exploring Curriculum
EDCR101.subject: Education
EDCR101.overview: An exploration of early childhood curriculum, with a particular focus on Te Whāriki, the early childhood curriculum framework.

EDCR102.title: The Languages of Children
EDCR102.subject: Education
EDCR102.overview: An exploration of the meaning-making experiences of very young children as they begin to communicate with the world and those around them.

EDCR131.title: English and Mathematics 1
EDCR131.subject: Education
EDCR131.overview: Introduces teaching and learning in English and mathematics and statistics. Examines the ways in which language, literacy and number concepts are acquired and explores knowledge fundamental to English and mathematics and statistics understanding.

EDCR133.title: Health and Physical Education
EDCR133.subject: Education
EDCR133.overview: Introduces the aims, philosophy and content of health and physical education. Examines effective pedagogies and resources required for critical thinking and action through learning, curriculum sequences and practical experiences.

EDCR135.title: Introduction to The New Zealand Curriculum and Social Sciences
EDCR135.subject: Education
EDCR135.overview: An introduction to The New Zealand Curriculum and the learning area of the Social Sciences.

EDPR101.title: The Practice of Early Childhood Teaching 1
EDPR101.subject: Education
EDPR101.overview: An introduction to professional, ethical, theoretical and pedagogical understandings, skills and dispositions important for early childhood teaching practice.

EDPR131.title: Te Weu
EDPR131.subject: Education
EDPR131.overview: An introduction to ethical, legal, and practical requirements of the primary teaching profession; and an examination of self-identities and policies related to te reo me ngā tikanga Māori.

EDUC101.title: Education and Society
EDUC101.subject: Education
EDUC101.overview: An examination of the political, social and cultural dimensions of contemporary educational practice.

EDUC102.title: Human Development
EDUC102.subject: Education
EDUC102.overview: Lifespan development in its social contexts.  A topic-based paper which includes the study of families, cultures within New Zealand, and disability.

ENGL121.title: English Literature: The Remix
ENGL121.subject: English
ENGL121.overview: Books are made out of other books; well-known English literary works are placed alongside historic and contemporary works that respond to them.

ENGL127.title: Essentials of Writing
ENGL127.subject: English
ENGL127.overview: Master the basics of writing clearly, persuasively, and powerfully across academic and professional contexts.

ENGL128.title: Essentials of Communication
ENGL128.subject: English
ENGL128.overview: Influence people and captivate colleagues: master the basics of speaking persuasively, listening actively, reading critically, and writing powerfully.

ENGL131.title: Controversial Classics
ENGL131.subject: English
ENGL131.overview: A study of literary classics that have attracted controversy for reasons including political content; issues of morality/obscenity; transgressing conventions of form; polemical works; questions of authorial identity and authenticity; controversies over prizes and literary merit.

ENTR111.title: Responsible Entrepreneurship
ENTR111.subject: Entrepreneurship
ENTR111.overview: Learn the importance of incorporating ethical, sustainable, inclusive, and indigenous values and mindsets in your entrepreneurial thinking and the opportunities this creates in new venture development.

ENTR112.title: Business Model Development and Innovation
ENTR112.subject: Entrepreneurship
ENTR112.overview: Work on business design and testing through ideation, prototyping, assessment and iteration. Learn about the process of finding a valuable, profitable, and scalable business model for your ideas.

ENVI111.title: Environment and Society
ENVI111.subject: Environment and Society
ENVI111.overview: Fundamentals of the Earth’s environmental systems; human impact on natural systems at global, national and regional scales.  Environmental hazards, concerns and issues; ethical, legislative, economic, and political responses and constraints.

FINC102.title: Business Mathematics
FINC102.subject: Finance
FINC102.overview: An integrated treatment of mathematics (algebra, matrices, calculus, optimisation) and modelling techniques, with an emphasis on applications.

FOSC111.title: Food in a Changing World
FOSC111.subject: Food Science
FOSC111.overview: An introduction to scientific and social aspects of food including global trends in food production for health and well-being, food choice, sensory properties, and issues around food safety and sustainability.

FREN131.title: Introductory French 1
FREN131.subject: French
FREN131.overview: Intensive French language for beginners and very near beginners.

GEND102.title: Bodies, Sexualities and Society
GEND102.subject: Gender Studies
GEND102.overview: Experiences of bodies, sexuality and identity, and the connections between them, in contemporary and historical settings, using New Zealand and international examples.

GEOG101.title: Physical Geography
GEOG101.subject: Geography
GEOG101.overview: An introduction to the geographic study of the Earth’s environmental systems, with particular emphasis on energy, landforms, vegetation, surficial materials and water.  Includes laboratory studies, tutorials and field work.

GEOG102.title: Geographies of Sustainable Futures
GEOG102.subject: Geography
GEOG102.overview: We face significant challenges including population growth, uneven development, over/under consumption, climate change, poverty, racism, and food security.  Human Geography helps us to understand these challenges and imagine sustainable futures.

GLBL110.title: Mapping our Interconnected World: An Introduction to Global Studies
GLBL110.subject: Global Studies
GLBL110.overview: What does it mean to be a “global citizen”?  Gain the cross-cultural and interdisciplinary perspectives required to face the challenges of globalisation and contribute to an inclusive, equitable, and sustainable world.

GREK112.title: Introductory Greek 2
GREK112.subject: Greek
GREK112.overview: A continuation of GREK111, including the study of texts taken from Classical Athens.

HEBR131.title: Introductory Biblical Hebrew 1
HEBR131.subject: Hebrew
HEBR131.overview: A paper for beginners covering the basics of Biblical Hebrew grammar and vocabulary, to enable students to read the Hebrew Bible in the original.

HEBR132.title: Introductory Biblical Hebrew 2
HEBR132.subject: Hebrew
HEBR132.overview: A continuation of HEBR131, including the translation and exegesis of selected passages from the Hebrew Bible.

HIST102.title: The Global Twentieth Century
HIST102.subject: History
HIST102.overview: An exploration of the twentieth century's wars and revolutions, booms and busts, dictators and democratic forces, providing a secure historical basis for understanding today's complex globalised world.

HIST107.title: New Zealand in the World from the 18th Century
HIST107.subject: History
HIST107.overview: New Zealand history in a global perspective: the way forces of imperialism, colonisation, capitalism and racial conflict have shaped modern New Zealand and its place in the world.

HIST108.title: From Medieval to Modern Europe
HIST108.subject: History
HIST108.overview: An examination of principal trends in the development of European civilisation between the early Middle Ages and the nineteenth century.

HIST123.title: Revolutions
HIST123.subject: History
HIST123.overview: An examination of the ways in which revolutions have transformed the world.

HUBS191.title: Human Body Systems 1
HUBS191.subject: Human Body Systems
HUBS191.overview: An introduction to the structure and function of the musculoskeletal, nervous, endocrine and immune systems in the human body, and to biostatistics.

HUBS192.title: Human Body Systems 2
HUBS192.subject: Human Body Systems
HUBS192.overview: An introduction to the structure and function of the human integumentary (skin), cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal/urinary and reproductive systems.

HUNT141.title: Understanding Human Nutrition
HUNT141.subject: Human Nutrition
HUNT141.overview: Basic understanding of key nutritional concepts and the importance of evidence-based nutrition for individual and population health.

INFO130.title: Fundamentals and practice of spreadsheets
INFO130.subject: Information Science
INFO130.overview: Introduces the core concepts and tools used to organise and manipulate tabular data. Covers basic spreadsheet calculation, modelling, visualisation and analysis skills for business and research.

JAPA131.title: Introductory Japanese 1
JAPA131.subject: Japanese
JAPA131.overview: An introductory course in reading, writing, speaking and listening to Japanese for students with no previous knowledge of the language.  The paper takes an integrated approach to the skills of language acquisition and includes basic material on the cultural heritage of the Japanese people.

JAPA132.title: Introductory Japanese 2
JAPA132.subject: Japanese
JAPA132.overview: A continuation of JAPA131, further developing students’ Japanese language skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening at an elementary level.  The paper takes an integrated approach to the skills of language acquisition and includes basic material on the cultural heritage of the Japanese people.

LATN112.title: Introductory Latin 2
LATN112.subject: Latin
LATN112.overview: A continuation of LATN111, including the study of texts chosen to illustrate Roman history and literature in the 1st century BC.

LING103.title: Language Myths
LING103.subject: Linguistics
LING103.overview: Examination of popular myths from a linguistics perspective. Includes topics such as the origins and nature of language, attitudes toward languages, and language policies.

LING111.title: A World of Languages
LING111.subject: Linguistics
LING111.overview: A tour through the world's 6,000 languages, learning where they come from and how they are put together: the foundational sounds, words, sentences and meanings of language.

LING140.title: Language, Brain, and Being Human
LING140.subject: Linguistics
LING140.overview: Humans uniquely are the big-brained animals with language. Explore what language is, how your mind makes it happen, and thereby what it means to be human.

MANT101.title: Managing for Performance
MANT101.subject: Management
MANT101.overview: Individual and group behaviour, communications, and the management of operations and human resources within organisations.

MAOR102.title: Māori Society
MAOR102.subject: Māori Studies
MAOR102.overview: An introduction to the theory and practice of Māori culture and society in traditional and contemporary contexts.

MAOR108.title: Waiata: Te Tīmatanga
MAOR108.subject: Maori Studies
MAOR108.overview: An introductory study of various forms of waiata (Māori performing art) including haka from traditional to contemporary times. A practicum component is also included.

MAOR111.title: Te Kākano 1
MAOR111.subject: Māori Studies
MAOR111.overview: He akoranga hei whakapakari i te reo o rātou kua tīmata kē ki te ako i te reo Māori. Ko te nuinga o te karaehe e whakaakona ana i te reo. Me mātua mōhio te akonga ki te mihi, ki te hanga i ētahi whakatakotoranga kōrero.  A post-introductory paper in Māori language that is taught mainly in Māori. Some previous knowledge of Māori language is essential.

MAOR112.title: Te Kākano 2
MAOR112.subject: Maori Studies
MAOR112.overview: He akoranga hei whakapakari i te reo kua akona i MAOR111. Ko te katoa o te karaehe e whakaakona ana i te reo Māori.  Development of the skills taught in MAOR111. Taught in Māori.

MAOR120.title: Introducing the Māori World
MAOR120.subject: Maori Studies
MAOR120.overview: An introduction to the Māori world, including cultural concepts and practices, Treaty of Waitangi, pronunciation, greetings, songs, and forms of language appropriate to work contexts. Includes cultural experience practicum.

MARI112.title: Marine Biology: The Living Ocean
MARI112.subject: Marine Science
MARI112.overview: An introduction to physical, chemical and biological processes and their co-dependencies in the global ocean system.

MART112.title: Marketing
MART112.subject: Marketing
MART112.overview: An introduction to the marketing environment, customer types, buyer behaviour, market segmentation and product, pricing, distribution and promotion issues in the context of domestic and international product and service markets.

MATH130.title: Fundamentals of Modern Mathematics 1
MATH130.subject: Mathematics
MATH130.overview: Core mathematical skills and background for applications across the quantitative sciences.

MATH140.title: Fundamentals of Modern Mathematics 2
MATH140.subject: Mathematics
MATH140.overview: Continuation from MATH 130 with an emphasis on mathematical thinking and formalisation and their importance for applications of mathematics.

MFCO101.title: Screen Form and Culture
MFCO101.subject: Media, Film and Communication
MFCO101.overview: An introduction to the basic analytical and critical skills as they apply to the study of moving images, specifically film. Issues of form, style and genre are addressed.

MFCO102.title: Media, Power, Society
MFCO102.subject: Media, Film and Communication
MFCO102.overview: Explores the impact of media such as advertising, social media and streaming media upon our values, work, knowledge and experience of everyday life.

MFCO103.title: Introduction to Communication Studies
MFCO103.subject: Media, Film and Communication
MFCO103.overview: An introduction to communication theories, media and genres.

MUSI101.title: Materials of Music 1
MUSI101.subject: Music
MUSI101.overview: An introduction to the materials of music, advancing students’ understanding of scales, modes, chords, rhythm and musical structure, illustrated with examples drawn from a wide range of music.

MUSI104.title: World Music
MUSI104.subject: Music
MUSI104.overview: An exploration of the world’s traditional, popular and contemporary musics in their cultural context.  (No prior musical knowledge required.)

MUSI132.title: Music Production 1
MUSI132.subject: Music
MUSI132.overview: An introduction to the technology of music, including computers and music software, sequencing, editing and recording techniques.

MUSI140.title: Performance Studies 1
MUSI140.subject: Music
MUSI140.overview: Tuition to develop solo performance skills through individual or small group instruction.

MUSI143.title: Instrumental or Vocal Performance 1
MUSI143.subject: Music
MUSI143.overview: The development of specialised instrumental or voice skills in music through individual lessons, group learning, and workshops

MUSI144.title: Music Ensemble 1
MUSI144.subject: Music
MUSI144.overview: The development of ensemble skills in music through directed group learning.

MUSI191.title: Introduction to Music
MUSI191.subject: Music
MUSI191.overview: An introduction to the theory of music, including notation and the foundations of key, harmony and tonality.

PACI101.title: Pacific Societies
PACI101.subject: Pacific Islands Studies
PACI101.overview: An introduction to selected Pacific societies in traditional and contemporary contexts, with a focus on indigenous perspectives.

PACI103.title: Languages and Cultures of the Pacific: An Introduction
PACI103.subject: Pacific Islands Studies
PACI103.overview: An introduction to a select Pacific language.

PACR101.title: Pacific Realities and University Learning
PACR101.subject: Pacific Realities and University Learning
PACR101.overview: An introduction to theories of learning and academic skills needed for independent learning and success at university especially designed for Pacific students new to tertiary study.

PHIL103.title: Ethical Issues
PHIL103.subject: Philosophy
PHIL103.overview: Theories about the status of moral claims (relativism, subjectivism, egoism, utilitarianism, etc.).  The rights and wrongs of specific issues (abortion, the environment, pacifism, etc.).

PHIL105.title: Critical Thinking
PHIL105.subject: Philosophy
PHIL105.overview: The ideas of reason, truth and argument.  What are the limits of argument?  Common fallacies of reasoning.  Traditional logic and its limitations.  Modern logic.  Non-deductive reasoning.

PHIL106.title: Radical Philosophy
PHIL106.subject: Philosophy
PHIL106.overview: Radical ideas about the human condition. Topics include existentialism, freedom,  authenticity, nihilism, feminism, meaning, and modernity. Authors studied include Nietzsche and Sartre.

PHSI131.title: Fundamentals of Physics I
PHSI131.subject: Physics
PHSI131.overview: The development of physical law from Newton to the revolutionary ideas of quantum physics formulated by Planck, Schrödinger, Heisenberg, Bohr and Einstein. The physics of the real world: motion, energy and its transfer, and an introduction to the quantum mechanical nature of light and matter. Applications of the principles of physics to a technological society.

PHSI191.title: Biological Physics
PHSI191.subject: Physics
PHSI191.overview: Foundations of physics for the health sciences including mechanics, properties of fluids and solids, thermodynamics, optics, electrostatics and DC circuits, and radiation and health.

PHSL101.title: Physiology for Sport and Exercise
PHSL101.subject: Physiology
PHSL101.overview: An introduction to the function of the musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, blood, respiratory, endocrine, gastrointestinal, immune, urinary and reproductive systems of the human body.

POLS102.title: Aotearoa New Zealand Politics – Introduction
POLS102.subject: Politics
POLS102.overview: The study of institutions and processes of the New Zealand political system.  Particularly the formal structure of government, political parties and interest groups, the citizen and political participation.

POLS105.title: Comparative Politics - Introduction
POLS105.subject: Politics
POLS105.overview: How political institutions and processes work across a range of countries. Introduces the comparative method and considers ways of conceptualising political systems and understanding the functions of their key institutions.

POLS110.title: Political Ideas in Action
POLS110.subject: Politics
POLS110.overview: A comprehensive exploration of the meaning and function of ideology, and a survey of the political ideologies that have shaped and continue to shape our world, including liberalism, socialism, anarchism, populism and conservatism.

POPH192.title: Population Health
POPH192.subject: Public Health
POPH192.overview: An introduction to the science of epidemiology, the study of the distribution and determinants of health and disease in human populations, and to different ways of understanding health.

PSYC111.title: Brain and Behaviour
PSYC111.subject: Psychology
PSYC111.overview: An introductory study of the biological bases of behaviour and development, neuropsychology, perception, and learning.

PSYC112.title: Human Thought and Behaviour
PSYC112.subject: Psychology
PSYC112.overview: An introductory study of developmental psychology, social psychology, health psychology, and psychopathology.

PTWY112.title: Essential Business Finance
PTWY112.subject: Pathway
PTWY112.overview: Introduces some characteristics of financial markets, including the time value of money, calculations of fair value for bonds and stocks, risk-return trade-offs, financing criteria and history of markets, and ethics.

PTWY121.title: Historical Worlds: Building States
PTWY121.subject: Pathway
PTWY121.overview: Examines how states have been built and how they have shaped the modern international environment, with a focus on key periods and events in the construction of Aotearoa New Zealand.

PTWY122.title: Contemporary Worlds: Our Challenges
PTWY122.subject: Pathway
PTWY122.overview: Examines key aspects of theories, institutions, and global issues in the contemporary international environment while also exploring a variety of geographic settings.

PTWY131.title: Introduction to the Human Body
PTWY131.subject: Pathway
PTWY131.overview: An introduction to the structure and function of the musculoskeletal, nervous, endocrine and immune systems in the human body, and to biostatistics.

PTWY132.title: Introduction to Plant Life
PTWY132.subject: Pathway
PTWY132.overview: An introduction to botany, how the study of plants aids our understanding of Earth’s history and human society, and how plants will respond to future environmental change.

RELS110.title: Introduction to the Scientific Study of Religion
RELS110.subject: Religious Studies
RELS110.overview: An introduction to scientific methods and their application to the study of religion, focusing on scientific explanations for religious belief and behaviour.

RELS111.title: Māori Spirituality and the World’s Religions
RELS111.subject: Religious Studies
RELS111.overview: In the first section we introduce Māori spirituality and religious practices. We then use this knowledge as a lens to understand and compare key components of Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam.

SOCI101.title: Sociology of New Zealand Society
SOCI101.subject: Sociology
SOCI101.overview: An introduction to core concepts in sociology, dealing in particular with class, gender and race/ethnicity.

SOCI102.title: Cultural and Social Identities
SOCI102.subject: Sociology
SOCI102.overview: An introduction to the social scientific analysis of culture, society and identity, including issues of identity politics, socialisation, the self in everyday life, stigma, the politics of ethnicity and the social dynamics of power.

SOCI103.title: Crime, Deviance and Social Transformation
SOCI103.subject: Sociology
SOCI103.overview: An introduction to research in criminology in global and local contexts, addressing debates related to crime, deviance and social transformation from a sociological viewpoint.

SOWK111.title: Working with People: The New Zealand Context
SOWK111.subject: Social Work
SOWK111.overview: An introduction to the context for academic and professional work in social services in New Zealand.

SPAN131.title: Introductory Spanish 1
SPAN131.subject: Spanish
SPAN131.overview: An introductory course in reading, writing, listening to, and speaking Spanish for students with no previous knowledge of the language.

SPAN132.title: Introductory Spanish 2
SPAN132.subject: Spanish
SPAN132.overview: A continuation of SPAN131, further developing skills in reading, writing, listening to, and speaking Spanish for students with some basic knowledge of the language.

SPEX101.title: Sport, Science and Society
SPEX101.subject: Sport, Physical Education and Exercise
SPEX101.overview: A critical overview of the nature and influence of sport in society, exploring how sport intersects with the fields of science, health, education, politics and the economy.

SPEX102.title: Principles of Exercise for Health and Performance
SPEX102.subject: Sport, Physical Education and Exercise
SPEX102.overview: An introduction to the principles and practice of exercise science, including common and relevant myths or misconceptions.

STAT110.title: Statistical Methods
STAT110.subject: Statistics
STAT110.overview: Descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, analysis of count data, analysis of variance and experimental design.  Sampling and design principles of techniques to build on in the implementation of research studies.

STAT115.title: Introduction to Biostatistics
STAT115.subject: Statistics
STAT115.overview: A paper for students in health-related subjects, in particular nutrition, food science, epidemiology, exercise science, psychology, and the health sciences.  Topics covered include the nature of random variation, the concepts of bias and confounding, study design, data description including risks and odds, binomial and normal distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, the control of confounders, critical appraisal, and the analysis of variance.

SURV120.title: Surveying and Spatial Science
SURV120.subject: Surveying
SURV120.overview: An introduction to the field methods, equipment, and computational procedures used in surveying and spatial science to measure, map and analyse Earth’s surface features and the built environment.

THEA152.title: Backstage for Theatre and Performance
THEA152.subject: Theatre Studies
THEA152.overview: A practical introduction to the stagecraft of working backstage in theatre and performance, including lighting, sound and stage management.

THEA153.title: Voice and Movement
THEA153.subject: Theatre Studies
THEA153.overview: The nature and philosophy of voice and movement in communication, and the development of personal awareness and requisite skills through practical training.

THEA154.title: Staging Worlds: Theatre and Performance
THEA154.subject: Theatre Studies
THEA154.overview: Using group practice and performance, this paper considers the live theatrical event and introduces the key principles, theories and methods utilised in Theatre Studies, including acting and improvisation techniques, devising (collaborative theatre-making), performance analysis, and critical enquiry.

TOUR101.title: Introduction to Tourism
TOUR101.subject: Tourism
TOUR101.overview: An introduction to the global principles that structure tourism, the nature and operation of the tourist industry and the impact, development and management issues that arise from tourism.

TOUR102.title: Global Tourism
TOUR102.subject: Tourism
TOUR102.overview: The major issues in world tourism as it is differentiated on a global regional basis; integrated illustrative case studies.
